reasoning: This directly targets a key load-bearing step in the paper’s argument for why linear/unbounded views are “fussy”: that value-per-unit-resource is extremely concentrated in rare best uses (fat-tailed), making near-optimal futures a narrow target. If the tail is thinner or value has many near-optimal basins, the paper’s practical conclusion about narrowness could weaken substantially, so the stakes are strategy-relevant (high cruciality). It is tightly tied to this paper’s specific machinery (fat tails + linearity + ‘most value wasted’), so paper-specificity is high. However, tractability is only moderate: we can do formal sensitivity analysis, toy models, and draw on empirical fat-tail regularities in other domains, but “advanced capability levels” and “true value-efficiency” depend on unknown future tech and contested moral assumptions, limiting decisiveness. The question is mostly clear, though terms like “plausible moral views” and operationalizing “value-efficiency” leave some ambiguity. It has a fairly explicit decision hook (fussy vs larger target), and little dead weight.
title: Fat-tailed value distribution assumptions and resource efficiency sensitivity
